channel.title: Max Memory?
channel.description:
My friends buying ram, of that sort they make 1gb modules but it says his computer can only support 1gb of ram. It has 2 ddr slots though. Would it work if he got 2, 1gb modules?
Type of Ram: PC2100 (266-MHz) DDR SDRAM
Type of computer: Dell Dimension 2350

item.title: Max Memory?
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Raymond.CC Blog

Make Windows 7, 8 and Vista 32-bit (x86) Support More Than 4GB Memory •...

One of the major differences between a 32-bit and 64-bit Windows is the support for more than 4GB of RAM. Here is good news for Windows 8, 7 and Vista users because we have some patches here to make your 32-bit Windows support more than 4GB of...

don’t know if that really works or not.

Read full topic

item.title: Max Memory?
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:19, topic:324692”][quote author=Greeny link=topic=421053.msg3103409#msg3103409 date=1263892221]
but at the same time I hope to god they aren’t using a 32-bit OS otherwise you’re a supreme moron.
[/quote]

Or he’s using one of the many 32-bit OS’s that supports >4gb ram? :/[/quote]

I’ve never managed to get 4gb RAM working on a 32 bit os out of the box.

Read full topic

item.title: Max Memory?
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Or he can go buy it, test it, and see if it works; if it doesn’t, take it back.

Read full topic

item.title: Max Memory?
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

I don’t see why your parents would need 8gb of RAM, but at the same time I hope to god they aren’t using a 32-bit OS otherwise you’re a supreme moron.

Also take into consideration it might be able to detect and use more RAM but the reason it doesn’t say to have that much in the manual is not because they didn’t test it, it’s probably more likely they did test it and it was unstable. If they know the average end user at the time would only need 1gb of RAM then the board doesn’t need to be optimized for more. I’m not saying it wont work, and that it will crash all the time but it could crash more often.

You shouldn’t have any problem, but you might. If you think the post of some random on the internet with no valid source is something to go off then you’re a little naive. Obviously the same can be said for my post but that’s why the manual was written and what does the manual say.

Read full topic

item.title: Max Memory?
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

I read it on a couple forums from people who have tried it. Update to the latest BIOS.

Read full topic

item.title: Max Memory?
item.dc:creator: @nacional nacional
item.description:
@nacional wrote:

Use www.crucial.com and use the crucial system scanner
it’ll tell you all your current info and the max amount of ram your cpu an handle.
even suggest some sites where he can buy the ram.

item.title: Max Memory?
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:11, topic:324692”]I don’t see why you would upgrade DDR ram now. I would just re-build a computer with a new mobo,cpu and most importantly DDR2/3 RAM. I would advise DDR3 mobo/ram because they are just a bit more expensive than DDR2 now.

mwiebelhaus, pc manufacturers cba to advertise the fact that all cpu’s have PAE.[/quote]

What happens if you can’t afford to build a new pc? What happens if the rest of the computer is fine but you need that little extra something to get the full potential out of it?

Read full topic

item.title: Max Memory?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

I don’t see why you would upgrade DDR ram now. I would just re-build a computer with a new mobo,cpu and most importantly DDR2/3 RAM. I would advise DDR3 mobo/ram because they are just a bit more expensive than DDR2 now.

mwiebelhaus, pc manufacturers cba to advertise the fact that all cpu’s have PAE.

item.title: Max Memory?
item.dc:creator: @Uriko Uriko
item.description:
@Uriko wrote:

[quote=“mwiebelhaus, post:9, topic:324692”][quote author=Uriko link=topic=421053.msg3092627#msg3092627 date=1263010467]
you really love those wrong answers don’t you, apart from being helpful your post was extremely arrogant, “stop listen to people who think that Dell manuals tell the truth which is bullshit” … why would we have any of reason to believe what the manual tells us is a lie?

good info though.
[/quote]

Older ones have alot of bullshit in them cause they don’t even test half of the shit, like extra memory which the max being offered at the time for upgrade was probably 1gb even though 1gb modules were out at the time and the motherboard was fully capable of utlizing 2gb, they felt since it wasn’t an option when the PC was offered they shouldn’t have to test it. I even seen this on a dell that my parents own from 2005 its a XPS 200 and it says the max supported is 4GB when I currently have 8GB in there and running.[/quote]interesting
+raep

Read full topic

Older ones have alot of bullshit in them cause they don’t even test half of the shit, like extra memory which the max being offered at the time for upgrade was probably 1gb even though 1gb modules were out at the time and the motherboard was fully capable of utlizing 2gb, they felt since it wasn’t an option when the PC was offered they shouldn’t have to test it. item.title: Max Memory?
item.dc:creator: @fellixombc fellixombc
item.description:
@fellixombc wrote:

[quote=“mwiebelhaus, post:5, topic:324692”]Yes this would work, I love the incorrect answers. The Dell Dimension 2350 uses Bluford e139765 motherboard which supports 2GB of DDR Ram so do it, and stop listen to people who think that Dell manuals tell the truth which is bullshit because I have a Dimension E310 next to me (the manual says 2GB Max and I have 4GB so…)

Tell your friend to buy this: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820231039[/quote]
He said the motherboard only supported a max of 1 gig of ram. I didn’t take the time and look into his friend’s actual computer. I just posted accordingly to his post.

Read full topic

item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Yes this would work, I love the incorrect answers. The Dell Dimension 2350 uses Bluford e139765 motherboard which supports 2GB of DDR Ram so do it, and stop listen to people who think that Dell manuals tell the truth which is bullshit because I have a Dimension E310 next to me (the manual says 2GB Max and I have 4GB so…)

Tell your friend to buy this: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820231039
